required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Clinical Study of the Effectiveness and Safety of a Disposable Intra-vaginal Device for Stress Urinary Incontinence (SUI)
clinical_study.official_title: A Clinical Study of the Effectiveness and Safety of a Disposable Intra-vaginal Device for Stress Urinary Incontinence

brief_summary.textblock: This study will evaluate the effectiveness of the pessary device by assessing reduction in urine leakage in approximately 80 women with SUI. Efficacy will be assessed by pad weight gain, frequency of stress urinary incontinence events, and a quality of life questionnaire.

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Responders for Pad Weight Gain or SUI Episodes
primary_outcome.time_frame: from the 14-day baseline period to the last 7 days of 14-day device usage period

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Stress Urinary Incontinence Episodes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from the 14-day baseline period to the last 7 days of 14-day device usage period
secondary_outcome.description: change from baseline as measured as reduction (improvement) in stress urinary incontinence episodes. Positive values are indicative of efficacious outcome.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from the 14-day baseline period to the last 7 days of 14-day device usage period
secondary_outcome.description: change from baseline as measured as reduction (improvement) in pad weight gain. Positive values are indicative of efficacious outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Quality of Life as Measured by Incontinence Impact Questionnaire (IIQ-7)
secondary_outcome.description: The IIQ-7 is based on 7 questions referring to areas which may have been influenced or changed by accidental urine loss and/or prolapse. These questions are assigned a value of, 0 = 'Not at all,' 1= 'Slightly,' 2 = 'Moderately,' or 3 'Greatly.' The IIQ-7 is scored by taking the average score of items and then multiplying the average by 33 1/3 to put scores on a scale from 0 to 100. A lower score is considered less impact to quality of life and a higher score reflects more impact to quality of life. In the same manner, a reduction in scores from baseline reflects improved quality of life.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Stress Urinary Incontinence Episodes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from the 14-day baseline period to the first 7 days of 14-day device usage period
secondary_outcome.description: change from baseline as measured as reduction (improvement) in stress urinary incontinence episodes. Positive values are indicative of efficacious outcome.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from the 14-day baseline period to the first 7 days of a 14-day device usage period
secondary_outcome.description: change from baseline as measured as reduction (improvement) in pad weight gain. Positive values are indicative of efficacious outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Responders for Pad Weight Gain or SUI Episodes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from the 14-day baseline period to the first 7 days of 14-day device usage period

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: 145 subjects entered the 2-week baseline phase and 55 subjects dropped before treatment

outcome.title: Percentage of Responders for Pad Weight Gain or SUI Episodes
outcome.time_frame: from the 14-day baseline period to the last 7 days of 14-day device usage period
outcome.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population. The "Number of Participants Analyzed" is the number subjects with available (non-missing) data in week 2

group.title: Pessary
group.description: disposable, single-use pessary disposable, single-use pessary

outcome.title: Change in Quality of Life as Measured by Incontinence Impact Questionnaire (IIQ-7)
outcome.description: The IIQ-7 is based on 7 questions referring to areas which may have been influenced or changed by accidental urine loss and/or prolapse. These questions are assigned a value of, 0 = ‘Not at all,’ 1= ‘Slightly,’ 2 = ‘Moderately,’ or 3 ‘Greatly.’ The IIQ-7 is scored by taking the average score of items and then multiplying the average by 33 1/3 to put scores on a scale from 0 to 100. A lower score is considered less impact to quality of life and a higher score reflects more impact to quality of life. In the same manner, a reduction in scores from baseline reflects improved quality of life.
outcome.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population. The "Number of Participants Analyzed" is the number subjects with available (non-missing) data at end of treatment

measure.title: Change in Quality of Life as Measured by Incontinence Impact Questionnaire (IIQ-7)
measure.description: The IIQ-7 is based on 7 questions referring to areas which may have been influenced or changed by accidental urine loss and/or prolapse. These questions are assigned a value of, 0 = ‘Not at all,’ 1= ‘Slightly,’ 2 = ‘Moderately,’ or 3 ‘Greatly.’ The IIQ-7 is scored by taking the average score of items and then multiplying the average by 33 1/3 to put scores on a scale from 0 to 100. A lower score is considered less impact to quality of life and a higher score reflects more impact to quality of life. In the same manner, a reduction in scores from baseline reflects improved quality of life.

reported_events.desc: All adverse events reported by the subject from study initiation [Visit 1 (Screening)] until study completion [Visit 3 (End-of-Treatment)] were recorded.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The STUDY SITE and PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR agree that all data, calculations, interpretations, opinions and recommendations regarding the STUDY (hereinafter referred to as “RESULTS”) shall be the property of P&G. The STUDY SITE and PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR agree to consider the RESULTS as INFORMATION subject to confidentiality restrictions

point_of_contact.organization: Procter & Gamble Company Global Clinical Sciences
